body.head.byline: By VIVIAN S. TOY; With Elsa Brenner, Suzanne Hamlin and Antoinette Martin

block.p: West Village Studio $499,000
MANHATTAN: 111 West 11th Street (between Sixth and Seventh Avenues), #2FE
A studio with a sleeping alcove and a washer and dryer in a walk-up building. Nancy Haber, Bellmarc Realty (212) 627-3000, ext. 215; www.bellmarc.com
MAINTENANCE: $535 a month
PROS: Charming prewar touches include an original fireplace and moldings. The renovated bathroom and kitchen have sleek finishes.
CONS: There is no bathtub. Built-in storage in the sleeping alcove can't help but be partly blocked by the bed.
Park Slope Co-op $375,000
BROOKLYN: 19 Fiske Place (near Garfield Place), # D1
A one-bedroom, one-bath fourth-floor co-op in a 1920s walk-up with common storage and laundry. Anita Culp, Corcoran Group (718) 210-4002; www.corcoran.com.
Open house Sunday, 2 to 4 p.m.
MAINTENANCE: $552 a month
PROS: On a charming blocklong street two blocks from Prospect Park, this unit has appealing prewar touches.
CONS: The living room looks out on a brick wall.
WESTCHESTER: 50 Sunnyside Avenue, Tarrytown

A three-bedroom, two-bath, three-story brick Tudor with casement widows and architectural details from the 1920s. It sits on a 0.18-acre terraced lot. Robin Birrittella, Legends Realty Group (914) 332-1010; www.legendsrealtygroup.net
TAXES: $14,680 a year

PROS: There are hardwood floors throughout, as well as a stone fireplace in the living room, granite counters and stainless steel appliances in the kitchen, and meticulous landscaping. The house is unconventional and eclectic, with charming nooks and crannies.
CONS: Because both the house and its gardens have many steps and levels (some steep), this house is not child-friendly.
1825 Colonial $449,000
NEW JERSEY: 305 West Mendham Road, Mendham

A two-bedroom, two-bath home on almost an acre of wooded property in a neighborhood of historic homes and hiking trails. A full restoration took place in the 1990s, and the kitchen was updated in 2004. The house has original pine floors and stairs, four fireplaces and woodstoves, a folk art mural of local history and a two-car garage with a finished loft. Janet Ellis, Coldwell Banker (973) 543-2552, ext. 231; www.coldwellbanker.com
TAXES: $6,651 a year
PROS: The house exudes the distinctive charm of a well-cared-for historic property.
CONS: There is a fairly busy street nearby. The loft space has no bathroom.
Gramercy Park Co-op $2,100,000
MANHATTAN: 44 Gramercy Park North (at Gramercy Park East), #4C
A two-bedroom, two-bath co-op in a prewar doorman building. Wendy Maitland, Brown Harris Stevens (212) 317-3660; www.brownharrisstevens.com
MAINTENANCE: $1,640 a month

PROS: The living room and master bedroom have lovely views of Gramercy Park, a private garden to which the building has several keys. The eat-in kitchen is cleverly laid out with unusual details like windowed drawers to hold pasta and a large refrigerator with a windowed door. Casement windows and antique bedroom doors give this apartment added character.
CONS: The second bedroom is a bit dark, as its window faces a wall.
